title: Judge rules Harvard does not discriminate against Asian Americans
text:
A federal judge on Tuesday handed Harvard University a major legal victory after ruling against a group of Asian American applicants who had sued the institution over claims they had been discriminated against in the admissions process.

In a 130-page ruling, Federal District Court Judge Allison Burroughs ruled that the college may consider race as part of its admissions process, writing that the court would not "dismantle a very fine admissions program that passes constitutional muster, solely because it could do better."

Burroughs noted that there is no evidence of "racial animus" or "intentional discrimination" beyond Harvard's use of a race-conscious admissions policy — a policy that she said allows the university to "achieve a level of robust diversity that would not otherwise be possible, at least at this time."

The lawsuit, which was filed in 2014 by the anti-affirmative action group Students for Fair Admissions, alleged that Harvard's race-based admissions process posed significant disadvantages for Asian American applicants. It also accused the university of engaging in "racial balancing" in its process of admitting prospective students.

The suit argued that the admissions process' "personal" rating system favored African American, white and Latino applicants over Asian Americans.

Edward Blum, a conservative lawyer with Students for Fair Admission who had led the challenge, said in a statement that the group would appeal the court's decision.

"We believe that the documents, emails, data analysis and depositions SFFA presented at trial compellingly revealed Harvard's systematic discrimination against Asian American applicants," Blum said. "SFFA will appeal this decision to the First Court of Appeals and, if necessary, to the U.S Supreme Court."

Students for Fair Admissions had argued that Asian American applicants to Harvard were less likely to be admitted to the university than other minority groups despite scoring higher on several objective measures, Bloomberg News noted.

Harvard has repeatedly denied the allegations , stating that it has not discriminated against applicants of any race or imposed racial quotas. The school has also asserted that Students for Fair Admissions was a "litigation vehicle designed to further the ideological objectives of its founder, Edward Blum."

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), which filed an amicus brief supporting Harvard in the case, praised the decision.

"We are glad the court recognized this lawsuit for what it is: a vehicle for an anti-affirmative action agenda, not a righteous fight for equality,” ReNika Moore, director of the ACLU's Racial Justice Project, said in a statement. “Harvard's right to set its own institutional goals and consider all aspects of a prospective student's background – including race – is Constitutional and critical to becoming a more inclusive society. We stand with the court in embracing the right to advocate the value of your unique background, heritage, and perspective."
description: A federal judge on Tuesday handed Harvard University a major legal victory after ruling against a group of Asian American applicants who had sued the institution over claims they had been discriminated against in the admissions process.
